instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound Fault
threads.message:
Hey Guys,

We've got a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> which had some liquid damage around <CHIP>U6420</CHIP> and we're experiencing a weird fault with the sound.

We hear the chime when the Mac boots (although it sounds like the speaker has blown but tested in another housing and still the same) and we also hear when the charger is connected but no sound once the Macbook fully boots.

Headphones work perfectly.

A google search suggested entering 'sudo killall coreaudiod' in terminal which then temporarily gets the sound working but then after 10-15seconds the sound cuts out again.

We've checked the audio settings and these all seem fine. Checked diode/voltages against known good and these are all fine also.

Is this a software based fault?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Sound Fault
threads.message: Check voltage and diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_INT_L</SIGNAL>.
